Explanations about Options.-prune:
True; if the file is a directory, do not descend into it. If -depth is given, then
 -prune has no effect. Because -delete implies -depth, you cannot usefully use
 -prune and -delete together.
 For example, to skip the directory `src/emacs' and all files and directories
 under it, and print the names of the other files found, do something like this:
 find . -path ./src/emacs -prune -o -print
Explanations about Options.-perm:
Any of the permission bits mode are set for the file. Symbolic modes are accepted
 in this form. You must specify `u', `g' or `o' if you use a symbolic mode. See
 the EXAMPLES section for some illustrative examples. If no permission bits in mode
 are set, this test matches any file (the idea here is to be consistent with the
 behaviour of -perm -000).
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-print:
Quoting is handled in the same way as for -printf and -fprintf. If you are using
 find in a script or in a situation where the matched files might have arbitrary
 names, you should consider using -print0 instead of -print.

Explanations about Options.-l:
Synonym for the -L option. Unlike -L, the max-lines argument is optional. If max-
 lines is not specified, it defaults to one. The -l option is deprecated since the
 POSIX standard specifies -L instead.
Explanations about Options.-I:
Replace occurrences of replace-str in the initial-arguments with names read from
 standard input. Also, unquoted blanks do not terminate input items; instead the
 separator is the newline character. Implies -x and -L 1.
Explanations about Options.-i:
This option is a synonym for -Ireplace-str if replace-str is specified. If the
 replace-str argument is missing, the effect is the same as -I{}. This option is
 deprecated; use -I instead.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Reopen stdin as /dev/tty in the child process before executing the command. This
 is useful if you want xargs to run an interactive application.
Explanations about Options.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.
Explanations about Options.-e:
This option is a synonym for the -E option. Use -E instead, because it is POSIX
 compliant while this option is not. If eof-str is omitted, there is no end of file
 string. If neither -E nor -e is used, no end of file string is used.
Explanations about Options.-t: Print the command line on the standard error output before executing it.
Explanations about Options.-r:
If the standard input does not contain any nonblanks, do not run the command.
 Normally, the command is run once even if there is no input. This option is a GNU
 extension.
Explanations about Options.-p:
Prompt the user about whether to run each command line and read a line from the
 terminal. Only run the command line if the response starts with `y' or `Y'.
 Implies -t.

Explanations about Options.--copy-dirlinks:
This option causes the sending side to treat a symlink to a directory as though it
 were a real directory. This is useful if you don’t want symlinks to
 non-directories to be affected, as they would be using --copy-links.
Explanations about Options.-a:
This is equivalent to -rlptgoD. It is a quick way of saying you want recursion and
 want to preserve almost everything (with -H being a notable omission). The only
 exception to the above equivalence is when --files-from is specified, in which case
 -r is not implied.
Explanations about Options.-v:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.

Explanations about Options.-i:
Integer attribute. n specifies the base to use when displaying the integer
 (if not specified, the base given in the first assignment is used).
 Parameters with this attribute may be assigned values containing arithmetic
 expressions.
Explanations about Options.-a: All new parameters are created with the export attribute.
Explanations about Options.-c: Impose a size limit of n blocks on the size of core dumps.
Explanations about Options.-n:
Do not execute any commands. Useful for checking the syntax of scripts (ignored
 if interactive).
Explanations about Options.-e:
Exit (after executing the ERR trap) as soon as an error occurs or a command
 fails (i.e. exits with a non-zero status). This does not apply to commands
 whose exit status is explicitly tested by a shell construct such as if, until,
 while or ! statements. For && or ||, only the status of the last command is
 tested.
Explanations about Options.-t:
Impose a time limit of n CPU seconds spent in user mode to be used by each
 process.
Explanations about Options.-r:
The shell is a restricted shell. This option can only be used when the shell is
 invoked. See above for a description of what this means.
Explanations about Options.-p:
The shell is a privileged shell. It is set automatically if, when the shell
 starts, the real UID or GID does not match the effective UID (EUID) or GID
 (EGID), respectively. See above for a description of what this means.
Explanations about Options.-m: Enable job control (default for interactive shells).

This command is  used  with --logdir. --logflush Clears (flushes) the log file after each write action. --logdebug Also  output  debug-level  messages  in  the log (equivalent to setting the env var QT_LOGGING_RULES="qt.*=true;*.debug=true"). ) --confdir <dirname> Uses the specified configuration directory. The ownCloud Client reads a configuration file.
